block.p: Camp David Talks Intensify As Clinton Wades In President Clinton plunged into issue-by-issue deliberations at the Mideast peace talks. Israeli and Palestinian officials said negotiators were working under Mr. Clinton's supervision to establish concrete points of accord and highlight the gaps.

Camp David Talks Intensify As Clinton Wades In President Clinton plunged into issue-by-issue deliberations at the Mideast peace talks. Israeli and Palestinian officials said negotiators were working under Mr. Clinton's supervision to establish concrete points of accord and highlight the gaps.

Indonesian Political Turmoil Two hundred members of Parliament extended a political standoff by rejecting President Abdurrahman Wahid's explanation for why he had ousted two cabinet ministers. The lawmakers demanded that Mr. Wahid go before the House of Representatives again to explain his actions.

Irish Guerrilla Released Michael Stone, a Protestant guerrilla who killed three mourners in Belfast during an I.R.A. funeral in 1988, was released from prison, the first of 88 fighters on both sides who will be freed in the last wave of early releases mandated by the Northern Ireland peace accord. Mr. Stone served 12 years of six life sentences for the three murders and three others that he was convicted of in 1989.

G.I. Testifies in Kosovo An American soldier gave evidence that might clear a Serb and his sons on trial for the killing of an Albanian last summer. The American said he had fired explosive rounds into a shed where the Albanian died. The trial has been considered a test of whether anyone who is not an Albanian can get a fair trial in Kosovo.

Death for Japan Sect Member A former member of the Aum Shinrikyo doomsday sect was sentenced to death in Tokyo for murders carried out before the fatal gas attack on a Tokyo subway in 1995. Satoru Hashimoto, 33, was found guilty of the 1989 murder of an anti-Aum lawyer, the lawyer's wife and baby, and for a 1994 Sarin gas attack in central Japan that killed seven.
Marc Reisner The environmental writer and advocate best known for his book ''Cadillac Desert: The American West and Its Disappearing Water'' was 51.

Voter Opinions on Issues Shape Race, Poll Finds Most Americans say they perceive pronounced differences in how Vice President Al Gore and Gov. George W. Bush would handle health care, taxes, the environment and Supreme Court appointments, a New York Times/CBS News Poll found. More than 7 out of 10 said there were genuine differences between the candidates, and more than half think those contrasts are more about issues than personal qualities.
Cheney Seen as Bush Choice Gov. George W. Bush was said to have decided on Richard B. Cheney as his running mate and is expected to announce it today.

Transcript of Clinton Interview During a wide-ranging interview with a senior Justice Department prosecutor in April, President Clinton denied asking political supporters to assist Webster L. Hubbell, a close friend who got $300,000 from associates of Mr. Clinton after he resigned from the Justice Department in 1994. Nearly half of the interview involved the president's long relationship with the Indonesian businessman James T. Riady.

New Senator From Georgia Gov. Roy Barnes, a Democrat, appointed his predecessor, Zell Miller, left, a fellow Democrat, to succeed the late Paul Coverdell, a Republican, as United States senator. Mr. Miller's appointment narrows the Republican margin in the Senate to 54 to 46.
H.M.O.'s Trim Medicare Rolls More than 900,000 elderly and disabled people will soon be dropped by H.M.O.'s pulling out of Medicare, the Clinton administration said.

DNA May Free Inmate Roy Criner, whose rape conviction attracted national attention in 1998 after the state's highest criminal court disregarded DNA evidence, is now receiving a recommendation from local officials that Gov. George W. Bush pardon him.

Fugitive Ordered Extradited The Philadelphia district attorney said French officials had ordered the extradition of Ira S. Einhorn, 60, once a charismatic leader of Philadelphia's counterculture who was convicted in absentia of murdering his girlfriend 22 years ago.

Central Park Closes For West Nile Spraying Officials said they had found mosquitoes infected with West Nile virus in Central Park and would spend the night blanketing all 843 acres with pesticides. The move caused a New York Philharmonic concert to be postponed until tonight. The park was to reopen today.

Ruling Against City on Welfare A federal judge rejected the Giuliani administration's efforts to move ahead with its welfare-to-work project, ruling the city could not turn any more welfare centers into job centers, which discourage the poor from seeking public assistance.

Ticket-Scalping Indictments Prosecutors said 16 people -- including 7 Yankee ticket agents and one who worked for the Mets -- had been indicted in a scheme that diverted blocks of tickets to scalpers.

Ex-Mayor of Newark Indicted Kenneth A. Gibson, 68, mayor from 1970 to 1986, was indicted on federal fraud, bribery and conspiracy charges involving his consulting firm's management of a $50 million school construction project.

School Budget Overhaul Urged The Campaign for Fiscal Equity, the plaintiff in a suit challenging New York State's system of allocating money to school districts, wants a judge to order a recalculation of the cost of providing a basic education to all public school students.

A Computer Teaches Itself A program called a neural network effectively taught itself to be proficient at checkers using the electronic equivalent of natural selection, two California scientists reported.

Mad Cow Deaths Rise in Britain Deaths from the human form of mad cow disease are increasing, British health officials say, though it is unclear whether the rise is the start of an epidemic or a statistical blip.
Replacing 'Babe' With Soy Some pediatricians say they are seeing more children and adolescents choosing vegetarian diets.

I.B.M. Management Overhaul Samuel J. Palmisano, 48, left, a senior vice president, will become president and chief operating officer, which seems to make him heir apparent to Louis V. Gerstner Jr., who discussed the management reorganization in an interview.

Nortel in Talks With Corning The telecommunications equipment giant Nortel Networks was said to be discussing a complex transaction to sell its fiber optics components business to Corning, the leading supplier of glass fiber. But some analysts and industry executives doubt the plan will get past the talking stage.

Flight Delays Underreported The Transportation Department's inspector general says that since 1988 the two government agencies that track airline delays have underestimated the amount of time lost by passengers by a total of 247 years.
Editorials: Urban mosquitoes; the Cheney option; Mr. Danforth's verdict on Waco; monarchs of their sports. Columns: Thomas L. Friedman.
